moves.1. d4: Queen's Pawn, my favorite opening, as I don't usually like the white side of such openings as the Sicilian and Caro-Kann.
moves.1... d5 2. c4 e6 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bg5: Standard QGD moves so far, the DSB develops to g5 before white plays a solidifying e3 push, so as the dear bishop doesn't end up trapped behind his own pawns.
moves.4... Bb4: This move is more unusual, but you can't really say it's inaccurate since it's still development. More typical in the position is 4...Be7 or maybe 4...c6 transposing into a Semi-Slav
moves.5. e3 Bxc3+: This I don't agree with, as trading a bishop for a knight so early is ill-advised in my eyes (unless provoked), seeing as it's much easier to open a position than to close it. These doubled pawns are of no trouble to White either, as c3 further strengthens the all important d4 pawn, and c4 does a good job contesting d5, and can always be traded off if need be. Better than this was 5...O-O, 5...Nbd7 and 5...Nc6
moves.6. bxc3 dxc4: This was also inaccurate, as this allows my LSB to develop in one move.
moves.7. Bxc4 h6: Again, I didn't like this, as my DSB wasn't much of a nuisance on g5. Black needs to castle and develop.
moves.8. Bxf6: Disregarding my earlier rule, but the bishop had to move, and I didn't feel it was much needed anymore at this point.
moves.8... Qxf6 9. Nf3 Nc6 10. O-O O-O 11. Bd3: Terrible mistake, as this allows the winning move
moves.12. Be4: The knight is skewered to the rook and all defenses fail.
moves.12... Bb7 13. Ne5: Black will end up losing material.
moves.13... Nxe5 14. dxe5 Qxe5 15. Bxb7: Black is down material now and the win should soon follow
moves.15... Rab8 16. Bf3 c5 17. Rc1 Rfd8 18. Q: Black should be trying to avoid these trades
moves.20... Rxd8: Qxd8 would hold on to the pawn, but either way the position is lost
moves.21. Qxb5 Rd2 22. a4 Ra2 23. Rd1: An extra piece, control of the open file and pawns to target would make the win easy, and from here black resigned.
